history.text: Hello
how are you today?
Hello! I am doing well. How about you?
Great, thanks for asking!
Have you seen this movie before?
So today, I'm here to tell you about The Great Gatsby. Yes, I just watched it.
I was a fan of the book. And I think Leonardo DiCaprio is pretty great.
Oh great, I'm dying to watch this movie, my favorite book!
He is great in almost every movie
Did they do it according to the book?
The art style is pretty amazing, I like the art deco era. And I agree! he's amazing in any role.
I'm dying to see how they portrayed this glamorous time, art deco, flappers, etc.

I thought they did okay for a book to film adaptation. I think it did more to show the Roaring Twenties and less of the "American Dream Dying" feel of the book. I suppose I had a different image of the book all together, it almost felt bleak in the book, even if it was described well. As if, in my head, the book had this almost de-colored view, dim, but the movie was bright and colorful
That's very interesting, I thought that the book was on the depressing side as well
but yes, the roaring twenties are very colorful and bright!

They made Nick less of that third party onlooker involved and made him a recovering alcoholic. The whole point of the book was really to have Nick be unrelated and just watching it all unfold. If I remember right, they made Nick Daisy's cousin instead of some completely unrelated third party. And yes, ahh the colors are great.
I'd still watch it just for the roaring twenties.
It didn't score that greatly, probably because of the whole not 'exactly' book to movie thing, but sometimes scenery and time period are enough to tell it's own story
yes,a great era of liberation and the theme of how the wealthy always care about money as the bottom line while the rest of the world  can die off for all they care!
Whenever I'm reading books that are made into movies, I try to treat them as two seperate things, in order to not be disappointed. And yeah. Very sad!
I read the book back in high school-but isn't there a scene where someone gets hit by a car and Daisy just could care less?

Oh the person that got hit by the car was Daisy's Husband's affair person, the mistress, and Daisy hit her, but it was generally an accident. People thought Myrtle was Gatsby's lover, it was a tangled mess. But Nick was like, I'll take care of it! in the movie.
yes, very sad!
I'm definitely interested in watching this movie, would be a nice break from all the super heroes movies and Marvel movies out there!
Not a whole  a lot of movies to stimulate the intellect these days lol!:-)
True, it's good to get something different in the mix. I like watching 'old time" movies. I mean, I've seen a few from the 1930s themselves, in black and white, and their stories are great.
I think it's funny they cast Tobey Maguire as Nick Carraway, because I just am like, Spiderman??
YEs, definitely, I love drama and period movies, especially medieval and viking!
Oh , really, that's funny!
I was always confused about what Tom (Daisy's Husband) saw in Myrtle in the book, as she was an overweight rude lady, compared to Daisy who just a pretty airhead without a thought.
I guess he just got tired of her
In the movie, at Gatsby's Funeral (Not in the book of course), every reporter painted Gatsby as Myrtle's lover and killer though. Depressing.
Yeah, hard to stay attracted to a pretty airhead.
yes, beauty isn't everything, she was stupid and cold!
Thanks so much for telling me about this movie, I'll definitely give it a try, I hope you have a great day!
Well, I hope you see it! I'm going to head out now. Thanks for talking with me!
Thank you again, take care!

uid2response.feedback: Amazing conversation and great movie, thanks!
